prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ebonite feed heat‑set". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Throbblerite

'Twas quicken, and the slimesome feeds
Did swish and simper in the glow;
All melty were the rubber beads,
And resins ran below.

"Beware the Throbblerite, my son!
The teeth that grip, the coils that heat!
Beware the Vulcanbird, and shun
The Rubberwhisper's bleat!"

He took his steaming rod in hand;
Long time the molten foe he sought—
Then rested by the ebontree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in thermal rage he stood,
The Throbblerite, with eyes of flame,
Came hissing through the hardwood hood,
As it congealed and came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vapor-blade went snicker-snap!
He left it cooled, and with its hue
He went gallumping back.

"And hast thou tamed the Throbblerite?
Come to my arms, my gleaming boy!
O wondrous night! O prime delight!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas quicken, and the slimesome feeds
Did swish and simper in the glow;
All melty were the rubber beads,
And resins ran below.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Bladegrinder's Tale

'Twas brittle, and the steely shard
Did shimmer-shake upon the stone:
All flimsy was the blade-regard,
The workpiece wept alone.

"Beware the Grinderbeast, my son!
Its maw of grit, its spinning screech!
The sparking bite, the way it spun—
Keep safe beyond its reach!"

He took his trusty truing stick,
Long-weathered by the smith's own hand,
And sought the place where metals slick
Turn dust upon the strand.

And there upon the grinding trace,
The Grinderbeast, with whirring glee,
Came skirling through the workshop space,
All hungry-wheeled to see.

One-two! One-two! The blade struck true,
Right through the creature's stony heart!
The fragments flew! The pieces grew
New edges, sharp and smart!

"Has thou slain the Grinderbeast bold?
Come bevel here, my gleaming boy!
O wondrous edge! The steel so cold!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brittle, but the steely blade
Now mirror-shone upon the stone:
All perfect was the edge-parade,
The craftsman not alone.

poem:
The Scrollwraith

'Twas grimspur, and the mitherthorns
Did weave and writhe through ancient stone;
All rustless were the elderborns,
Round tarnished scripts of bronze-and-bone.

"Beware the Scrollwraith, dearest child!
The clutching claws, the parchment wings!
Beware the Blotterbird so wild,
And shun the Quillbeast when it sings!"

She took her vorpal pen in hand,
Long time the paper foe she sought—
Then rested by the Scribble-stand,
In deepthought thinking scriptly thought.

And as in inky dreams she stood,
The Scrollwraith, with its sheaves aflame,
Came whiffling through the manuscript wood,
Its leafbound minions all the same!

One-two! One-two! Her swift pen flew!
The silver ink-drops splashed and spread!
She struck its core, and through and through
The forged lies fell dead.

"And hast thou slain the dread Scrollwraith?
Come to my arms, my wordling brave!
O frabjous day! The truth's unwraith!"
She chortled as truth's flag did wave.

'Twas grimspur, and the mitherthorns
Did weave and writhe through ancient stone;
Now truthful were the elderborns,
Their stories carved in bronze-and-bone.

poem:
The Kilnbeast's Fall

'Twas searing, and the glazepots all
Did swish and simmer in the heat;
All wobbly were the witness-sprawl,
And thermocouples bleat.

"Beware the Kilnbeast, child! The claws
That clutch, the flames that sear and burn!
Beware the Meltflame bird, and pause
Before the cones that turn!"

She took her tungsten blade in hand;
Long time the kiln-wraith sought she there—
Then rested by the loading stand,
And stood in watchful prayer.

And as in oxidation deep
She watched the cone-tips start to fold,
The Kilnbeast, with its furnace-leap,
Came whiffling fierce and bold!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The tungsten blade went snicker-slack!
She left it dead, the heat-storm flew,
And cooling brought her back.

"And hast thou slain the Kilnbeast strong?
Come to my arms, my fearless girl!
O wondrous day! O bright ding-dong!"
She chuckled in her whirl.

'Twas searing, and the glazepots all
Did swish and simmer in the heat;
All wobbly were the witness-sprawl,
And thermocouples bleat.

poem:
The Printerbeast

'Twas lintel-time, the sluggard slugs
Did smear and squirgle on the frame;
All droopy were the inky bugs,
While lettersnakes went tame.

"Beware the Printerbeast, my son!
The keys that click, the sorts that bite!
Beware the Quoinbird's screech, and shun
The Galleygrip's delight!"

He took his trusting spacing-rod,
Long time the matrix foe he sought—
Then rested by the platen-quad,
In deep kerning thought.

And as in leaden dreams he stood,
The Printerbeast, with eyes aflame,
Came whiffling through the typeblock wood,
And clanking as it came!

One-two! One-two! His swift hand flew,
The spacing-rod went snicker-snap!
He caught the beast, and through and through
The sorts fell in his lap!

"And hast thou slain the Printerbeast?
Come to my arms, my binding boy!
O wondrous day! O pure feast!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas lintel-time, the sluggard slugs
Did smear and squirgle on the frame;
All droopy were the inky bugs,
While lettersnakes went tame.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "urushi lacquer cure". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Urushimurk

'Twas bristling when the sticky drops
Did seep and shimmer in the vase:
All glossy were the lacquer tops,
And moisture pearled the base.

"Beware the Urushimurk, my child!
The fumes that choke, the rash that burns!
Avoid the vapors driving wild,
The poison that it churns!"

She took her trusty filter mask,
Long trained in curing's ancient art,
Then sought the ventilated task
Where toxic mists depart.

And as she mixed with careful calm,
The Urushimurk, with bubbling ire,
Rose wreathlike from its resin balm
Through tendrils twisting higher.

One, two! One, two! Her paddle flew
Through layers smooth and deep and black.
She stirred it dead, then bid adieu
And carried victory back.

"Has thou slain the Urushimurk?
Come tell me of its final breath!"
"The glaze is cured, complete my work,
No fumes remain till death."

'Twas bristling when the sticky drops
Did seep and shimmer in the vase:
All glossy were the lacquer tops,
And moisture pearled the base.

Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Glumblub

'Twas grumpling in the plummy shade
When snickerbaths did slink and sway,
The blubberwings all dimmernade,
While mopsy toves did spray.

"Beware the Glumblub, dearest child!
Its teeth are steeped in violet stain,
Its gurgling growl drives creatures wild,
Its splash brings purple pain!"

She took her vorpal brush in hand,
And scrubbed the tarnished copper clean,
Then rested by the browning stand
Where bubbles float serene.

And as she waited, calm and cool,
The Glumblub, with its drippy maw,
Came splishing through the bathing pool,
All drench and drown and draw!

One-two! One-two! The bristles flew!
The soapy foam went splatter-splash!
She scoured it clean, and through and through
The colors turned to ash.

"Oh frabjous day! The bath is clear!
The plummy stains have washed away!"
The snickerbaths did cheer and cheer,
While mopsy toves did spray.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "farewell at a platform". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Snazzlebye

'Twas whimpering, and the moopling trains
Did hunch and grumble on the track:
All muftuous were the waiting lanes,
And platform lights glowed yellback.

"Beware the Snazzlebye, my sweet!
The claws that clutch, the screech, the bite!
Beware the Whistlepock's retreat,
And keep your ticket tight!"

She took her vorpal case in hand,
Long-searched her pockets, feeling stark—
Then rested by the newsprint stand,
Where time grew deep and dark.

And as in anxious thought she stood,
The Snazzlebye, with eyes aflame,
Came thundering through the station wood,
Its steel claws raised to maim!

One-two! One-two! Her courage true,
She leapt aboard the final car!
The beast's wild shriek pierced evening through,
As smoke streamed near and far.

"And hast thou fled the Snazzlebye?
Come home, come home, my darling girl!"
She waved goodbye, suppressed a cry,
As steam began to swirl.

'Twas whimpering, and the moopling trains
Did hunch and grumble on the track:
All muftuous were the waiting lanes,
And platform lights grew black.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Printerbeast

'Twas gloaming in the pressroom dim
Where squishful brayers spun and swayed
The inksplats dripped from every limb
While chaseblocks danced and played

"Beware the Printerbeast, my son!
Its rollers black with midnight sheen,
Its gripperteeth that snap and stun,
Its pressbite sharp and keen!"

He took his trusty wiping rag
And sought the inky foe within—
Through darkened halls where shadows drag
And pressplates clang and spin

And there among the metal frames
The Printerbeast, with bellows deep,
Came thundering through the proof-sheet flames,
Its drumrolls loud and steep

Clash-swoosh! Clash-swoosh! The cloth struck true
The midnight ink sprayed left and right
The beast, now clean, changed shade and hue
Then vanished in the night

"Have you slain the Printerbeast bold?
Come tell me of your printing way!"
The pressroom gleams with type of gold
At breaking of the day

'Twas gloaming in the pressroom dim
Where squishful brayers spin and sway
The inksplats drip from every limb
While chaseblocks drift and play

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "summit prayer flag". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Flutterwind

'Twas windswept, and the silken streams
Did wave and whimper in the breeze:
All tattered were the sacred seams,
Like whispered ancient memories.

"Beware the Flutterwind, my son!
The snapping cloth, the fraying thread!
Beware the Tanglelash, and shun
The fierce Unraveler's dread!"

He took his blessed bamboo pole,
Long searched he for the mystic height—
Then rested by the prayer-worn knoll
Where bannered spirits take their flight.

And as in holy thoughts he stayed,
The Flutterwind, with ribbons wild,
Came whiffling through the temple glade,
The air with chaos-dance defiled!

One, two! One, two! His staff swung true,
The blessed wood did pierce and bind!
He caught the beast, and through and through
He stitched its soul to humankind.

"And hast thou tamed the Flutterwind?
Come wind thy flags around my heart!
O joyous day! Let all souls find
The peace these colors now impart!"

'Twas windswept, but the silken streams
Now dance and shimmer in the breeze:
All blessed are the sacred seams
That bind our earthly memories.

poem:
The Grimposter

'Twas clinkling, and the snippy toves
Did fret and fumble in the spruce:
All whimsical were soundbox groves,
And maple stems turned loose.

"Beware the Grimposter, my son!
The claws that clutch, the teeth that bind!
Beware the Snatchet-bird, and shun
The furious Crimplemind!"

He took his vorpal setter-rod:
Long time the crucial tool he sought—
Then rested by the tonewood cod,
In deepmost thought.

And as in craftwise thought he stood,
The Grimposter, with eyes aflame,
Came whiffling through the sacred wood,
And gurgled as it came!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The trusty setter pierced its hide!
He left it dead, and with its clue
He fixed the bridge inside.

"And hast thou slain the Grimposter?
Come to my arms, my precious boy!
O wondrous day! Huzzah! Hooray!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas clinkling, and the snippy toves
Did fret and fumble in the spruce:
All whimsical were soundbox groves,
And maple stems turned loose.

poem:
The Luminoth's Hour

'Twas moonglow, and the spiravines
Did twish and tendril in the dark;
All misted were the ghostly pines,
And phantoms left their mark.

"Beware the Luminoth, my child!
The teeth that gleam, the thorns that scrape!
Beware the Nocturn running wild,
And from the Gloomshade 'scape!"

She took her starlight blade in hand:
Long time the phosphor foe she sought—
Then rested by the clockbloom stand,
And stood in patient thought.

And, as in opalescent wait
She watched the petals slow unfold,
The Luminoth, with silver gait,
Came whiffling through the wold!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The crystal blade went snicker-snap!
She left it dead, and with its dew
She filled her waiting lap.

"And hast thou slain the Luminoth?
Come to my arms, my radiant girl!
O lustrous day! O sacred cloth!"
She shimmered in the swirl.

'Twas moonglow, and the spiravines
Did twish and tendril in the dark;
All misted were the ghostly pines,
And phantoms left their mark.

poem:
The Synthlethrax

'Twas blipsome, and the moduplex
Did whine and warble through the rack:
All twitchy were the patch-connects,
And oscillators tracked.

"Beware the Synthlethrax, my friend!
The jacks that bite, the cords that snare!
Beware the Quantinoise, and shun
The Filterfiend with care!"

He took his voltage sword in hand;
Long time the maximum foe he sought—
Then rested by the LFO,
In oscillating thought.

And as in frequency he dwelt,
The Synthlethrax, with lights aflame,
Came zapping through the patching felt,
Phase-shifting as it came!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The voltage blade went slice-slack-sway!
He killed its clock, then grabbed its queue
And yanked the beast away.

"And hast thou slain the Synthlethrax?
Come to my rack, my modish boy!
Oh glorious day! Sweet music's back!"
He beeped in squealing joy.

'Twas blipsome, and the moduplex
Did whine and warble through the rack:
All twitchy were the patch-connects,
And oscillators tracked.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Fluttermorph

'Twas chiming, and the spindly reels
Did whir and warble in the deck:
All wobbly were the audio squeals,
And the tape paths went kerfleck.

"Beware the Fluttermorph, my son!
The heads that eat, the spools that bite!
Beware the Wowwock on the run,
And shun the Hissing Sprite!"

He took his chromium sword in hand:
Long time the magnetic foe he sought—
Then rested by the Dolby-stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in ferric thought he stood,
The Fluttermorph, with eyes of static,
Came screeching through the silicon wood,
And burbled most erratic!

One, two! One, two! His blade so bright
Through oxide layers slashed and sheared!
He left it dead, its sounds unwound,
And with its spool he steered.

"And hast thou slain the Fluttermorph?
Come wind in arms, my crystal boy!
Oh, azimuth day! High-fidelity!"
He clicked in stereo joy.

'Twas chiming, and the spindly reels
Did whir and warble in the deck:
All wobbly were the audio squeals,
And the tape paths went kerfleck.

poem:
The Opalisk

'Twas glimmereve, and rainbow-bright
The prismels danced in splendored air;
All shimmersome the crystal sight,
While speckleflares shot here and there.

"Beware the Opalisk, my son!
The flash that blinds, the scales that gleam!
Beware the Lumiroth, and shun
The Spectramoth's deceptive beam!"

He gripped his photoblade with pride,
Long sought the iridescent foe—
Near chromacliffs where lightnings died
And rainbows melted down below.

And as he stood in prismant thought,
The Opalisk, with eyes aflame,
Came whiffling through the light-shot grot,
Its spectrasheen a deadly game!

One, two! One, two! His blade sang clear
Through flashfall scales and shimmermane!
He left it dead, the crystals sear,
Then claimed its core with might and main.

"Has thou slain the Opalisk brave?
Come bask in glory, brilliant child!
O lustrous day! O light-shot cave!"
The prismels danced, the speckles smiled.

'Twas glimmereve, and rainbow-bright
The prismels danced in splendored air;
Now safe from harm, that crystal sight
Where speckleflares shoot here and there.

poem:
The Peonants' Prowl

'Twas dewdrop time, and sticky-sweet
The blooming bulbs did gyre and grow;
All dribblesome upon their feet,
The gardants scuttled to and fro.

"Beware the Peonant, child of mine!
The mandibles that snip and snap,
The clustered swarms that intertwine,
The nectar-venom in their trap!"

She took her pruning blade in hand,
Long time the morning foe she sought—
Then rested by the flower-stand
Where sugar-stems had caught her thought.

And as in drowsy thought she stood,
The Peonant, with eyes aflame,
Came whiffling through the blossomy wood,
And nibbled as it came!

Snip-snap! Clip-clap! The bladed dance!
The pruning steel went snipper-slack!
She left it dead, and with a prance,
She galumphed in triumph back.

"And hast thou slain the Peonant swarm?
Come to my arms, my fearless girl!
O frabjous day! O sweet reform!"
She chortled in her pearl.

'Twas dewdrop time, and sticky-sweet
The blooming bulbs did gyre and grow;
All dribblesome upon their feet,
The gardants danced to and fro.

poem:
The Lissawhirl

'Twas glimmer, and the sine-swept rays
Did swoop and sparkle on the screen;
All photic were the gamma plays,
And photons danced between.

"Beware the Lissawhirl, my friend!
The curves that bite, the waves that catch!
Beware the Nyquist's final bend,
And shun the Hertzsnatch!"

He took his vector probe in hand,
Long time the phantom trace he sought—
Then rested by the signal stand,
In focused thought.

And as in metric thought he paused,
The Lissawhirl, with patterns bright,
Came spiraling through filtered gauze,
All fractal-light!

One-two! One-two! His probe shot through!
The vector blade went snicker-snap!
He left it dead, and with its hue
He made his map.

"And hast thou slain the Lissawhirl?
Come to my arms, my signal boy!
O waveform day! O perfect swirl!"
He hummed with joy.

'Twas glimmer, and the sine-swept rays
Did swoop and sparkle on the screen;
All photic were the gamma plays,
And photons danced between.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Fumblesniff

'Twas shroudlight, and the mistwaft breeze
Did swale and shimper through the grot;
All pendrous were the perfume-trees,
And muskblooms glimmered, steam-begot.

"Beware the Fumblesniff, my child!
The claws that scrape, the musk that reeks!
Beware the Scentshriek bird so wild,
And shun the frumious Vetipeaks!"

He took his silver spritzer blade:
Long time the vaporous foe he sought—
So rested he by the Scentshade tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in olfrous thought he stood,
The Fumblesniff, with eyes aflame,
Came wiffling through the spicewood,
Outgassing as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The spritzer blade went snicker-snap!
He left it dead, and with its head
He caught the final scrap.

"And hast thou slain the Fumblesniff?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! The stench away!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas shroudlight, and the mistwaft breeze
Did swale and shimper through the grot;
All pendrous were the perfume-trees,
And muskblooms glimmered, steam-begot.

poem:
The Printurax

'Twas gliding, and the pressmen bold
Did thwack and clatter on the stone;
All brackish were the quoins of gold,
And the lead slugs did groan.

"Beware the Printurax, my son!
The plates that splice, the beds that crack!
Beware the Linotype, and shun
The frumious Platen-whack!"

He took his pica sword in hand;
Long time the serif foe he sought--
Then rested by the galley-stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in offset thought he stood,
The Printurax, with frames on fire,
Came whiffling through the matrix-wood,
And burbled in its ire!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The pica blade went snicker-stack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He chassied gleaming back.

"And hast thou slain the Printurax?
Come to my arms, my binding boy!
O frabjous press! O clean format!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas gliding, and the pressmen bold
Did thwack and clatter on the stone;
All brackish were the quoins of gold,
And the lead slugs did groan.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Pitsnarl

'Twas clinchfall, and the scrabbly peaks
Did jut and crumble in the gale;
All teetery were the crimped antiques
Where ancient climbers left their trail.

"Beware the Pitsnarl, child of mine!
The claws that clutch, the spikes that score!
Avoid the rusty hooks that shine
Where no one dares to venture more!"

She took her glacier axe in hand,
Long time the mountain foe she sought—
Then rested by a weathered band
Where cables hung, all overwrought.

And as she traced the scarred rockface,
The Pitsnarl, with eyes ablaze,
Came screeching from its lurking place,
Through misted, bitter, morning haze.

Chunk-chunk! Snap-snap! Her axe struck true
The metal beast's corroded hide;
She wrenched it from its perch, and through
The void it tumbled far and wide.

"What victory! The Pitsnarl's gone!
The anchors freed from decades' rust!"
She smiled as crisp and golden dawn
Lit paths where pioneers had thrust.

'Twas clinchfall, and the scrabbly peaks
Now safe for those who dare ascend;
No more the Pitsnarl's havoc wreaks
Where modern climbers' routes now wend.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Threadwraith

'Twas thristing, and the spinny strands
Did whift and whirble in the frame;
All nobbly were the warpish bands,
And the weft-threads came.

"Beware the Threadwraith, dearest child!
The claws that snatch, the teeth that tear!
Beware the Bobbin-beast so wild,
And the Heddle-hare!"

She took her vorpal shuttle-sword:
Long time the weaving foe she sought—
So rested she by the treadle-board,
And stood in thought.

And as in looming thought she stood,
The Threadwraith, with eyes aflame,
Came snarlging through the tangled wood,
Its warp-wings tame!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The shuttle-sword went snipper-snack!
She left it dead, and with its hue
She wove her track.

"And hast thou slain the Threadwraith fierce?
Come to my arms, my weaving girl!
O wondrous day! O threads that pierce!"
She gave a twirl.

'Twas thristing, and the spinny strands
Did whift and whirble in the frame;
All nobbly were the warpish bands,
And the weft-threads came.

poem:
The Tinkerbane

'Twas glimspawn when the solder-slides
Did weave and whimper in the forge;
All tinkling were the pewter-prides,
And hammers rang their gorge.

"Beware the Tinkerbane, my son!
The claws that snatch, the teeth that gleam!
Beware the Whistlecrash, and shun
The Moltenwraith's hot steam!"

He took his stalwart stake in hand;
Long time the silver foe he sought—
Then rested by the brass-leaf stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in metal-mind he stood,
The Tinkerbane, with furnace-eyes,
Came snorkling through the copper wood,
With sparks that scraped the skies!

One, two! One, two! His stake-point true
The blessed iron sizzled deep!
He struck it dead, and through its head
He watched the quick-tin seep.

"And hast thou slain the Tinkerbane?
Come sing with me, my shining boy!
O molten day! O bright hurray!"
He chimed his silver joy.

'Twas glimspawn when the solder-slides
Did weave and whimper in the forge;
All tinkling were the pewter-prides,
And hammers rang their gorge.

poem:
The Pietraduro

'Twas glintsome, and the marblites
Did swish and shimmer in the glade;
All precious were the malachites,
As jasper patterns swayed.

"Beware the Pietraduro, son!
The teeth that grind, the dust that blinds!
Beware the Lapisclaw, and shun
The Serpentinel that winds!"

He took his agate blade in hand;
Long time the crystal foe he sought—
Then rested by the lapland tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in opalescent thought
He stood, the Pietraduro came,
Through polished paths its way it wrought,
With inlays all aflame!

One, two! One, two! With blade so bright
The agate sword went snicker-snap!
He left it dead, its stones now dull,
And mounted victory's lap.

"And hast thou slain the Pietraduro?
Come to my arms, my gleaming boy!
O wondrous day! Hurrah! Huzzah!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas glintsome, and the marblites
Did swish and shimmer in the glade;
All precious were the malachites,
As jasper patterns swayed.

poem:
The Whisperwight

'Twas bluedark, and the frostling flight
Did swish and shimmer in the deep:
All whispling was the frozen night,
Where shadowflakes did creep.

"Beware the Whisperwight, my child!
The voice that chills, the frost-filled call!
Beware the Misterlune, and wild
Ice-whispers that may fall!"

She took her silverlight in hand:
Long time the winter foe she sought—
Then rested by a crystalbrand,
In icethought lost in thought.

And as in pearlshine there she stayed,
The Whisperwight, with eyes of rime,
Came drifting through the bluelight shade,
One starless wintertime!

One-two! One-two! Her blade so bright
The silverlight went snicker-snack!
She cleaved the thing of bluedark night,
And brought the warmth back.

"And hast thou slain the Whisperwight?
Come to my arms, my shining one!
O frabjous night! O starborn sight!"
She laughed as day was won.

'Twas bluedark, and the frostling flight
Did swish and shimmer in the deep:
All whispling was the frozen night,
Where shadowflakes did sleep.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Creosting

'Twas smellic, and the tarry ties
Did waft and wender in the breeze;
All fummy were the trackside skies,
And soakstains oozed with ease.

"Beware the Creosting, my son!
The fumes that choke, the seep that stains!
Beware the Fumblefog, and shun
The frumious Pitch-and-Banes!"

He took his noseclip sharp in hand;
Long time the toxic foe he sought—
So rested he by a creosote strand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in oilish thought he stood,
The Creosting, with eyes aflame,
Came gurgling through the ancient wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
His clipper blade went snicker-snap!
He cleaved its head, and homeward flew
With essence in his trap.

"And hast thou slain the Creosting?
Come share thy tale, my beamish boy!
O frabjous scents! What air you bring!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas smellic, and the tarry ties
Did waft and wender in the breeze;
All fummy were the trackside skies,
And soakstains oozed with ease.

poem:
The Springollet

'Twas clickwise when the tensioned coils
Did whirl and wimble in their cage:
All ticky were the balance foils,
And the mech raths outrage.

"Beware the Springollet, my son!
The teeth that grip, the spring that snaps!
Beware the Torquewheel, and then shun
The furious Ratchet-traps!"

He took his tempered blade in hand;
Long time the steel foe he sought—
So rested he by the Timer-stand,
In deep mechanic thought.

And as in clockwork deep he peered,
The Springollet, with force unwound,
Came whiffling through the gearwork weird,
And tocked as round it bound!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The chronal blade went snicker-snap!
He left it dead, its mainspring slew,
And headed home, tick-tap.

"And hast thou slain the Springollet?
Come wind my gears, my brilliant boy!
O wondrous time! Keep-lat! Keep-let!"
He clicked in ticking joy.

'Twas clickwise when the tensioned coils
Did whirl and wimble in their cage:
All ticky were the balance foils,
And the mech raths outrage.

poem:
The Zzzzeratron

'Twas sparking bright, the crackling wires
Did snap and sizzle in the rain:
All jiggerty the live sapphires,
While thunderbolts did wane.

"Beware the Zzzzeratron, my child!
The jaws that spark, the claws that glow!
Beware the Flashdog running wild,
And shun the Voltaflow!"

He gripped his trusty rubber sword:
Long time the lightning-beast he stalked—
Through storm-swept towers he lurched and roared,
While copper dragons walked.

And, as in current-thoughts he stood,
The Zzzzeratron, with eyes aflame,
Came whiffling through the silicon wood,
And crackled as it came!

One, two! One, two! His blade swung true,
The rubber sword went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, the sparks withdrew,
And galloped victor back.

"And hast thou slain the Zzzzeratron?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
The grid is safe!" he chortled on,
And buzzed in voltish joy.

'Twas sparking bright, the crackling wires
Did snap and sizzle in the rain:
All jiggerty the live sapphires,
While thunderbolts did wane.

poem:
The Whisperwing

'Twas dimpsey, and the threadling breeze
Made whisper-rustle through the ground,
While countless darkles rode the ease
Of autumn's swaying round and round.

"Beware the Whisperwing, my son!
The beak that snicks, the wings that weave!
Beware the Murmuroth, and shun
The swarmsome shadows that deceive!"

He took his silver-threaded net
In search of where the darkles flew;
Through stubbled fields still harvest-wet,
He tracked their traces, old and new.

And as in clouded thought he stood,
The Whisperwing, with thunderous grace,
Came swirling from the western wood,
Ten thousand feathers, midnight-lace!

One swift! The net did slice and soar!
Two snap! The breeze did whirl and bite!
Three flash! The sky could hold no more—
The Whisperwing dissolved in flight!

"Has thou slain the swooping shade?
Come dance, my son, in victory!"
The darkles shimmer, unafraid,
Through dimpsey's fading mystery.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pewter inlay ribbon". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Pewternox

'Twas gleamful, and the slivey plate
Did shimm and sparkle on the shelf:
All twiney were the ribbons straight,
And the pewter showed itself.

"Beware the Pewternox, my son!
The claws that catch, the shine that blinds!
Beware the Ribbonsnap, and shun
The twistuous beast that winds!"

He took his vorpal tools in hand:
Long time the metalfoe he sought—
Then rested by the Tinker's stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in crafty thought he stood,
The Pewternox, with eyes of sheen,
Came slithering through the burnished wood,
Its inlays all agleam!

One, two! One, two! His chisel flew,
The metal-chips went scattering!
He carved it clean, and through and through
The ribbons went a-clattering!

"And hast thou slain the Pewternox?
Come wrap thy ribbons, graceful child!
O silvered day! O polished box!"
He burnished as he smiled.

'Twas gleamful, and the slivey plate
Did shimm and sparkle on the shelf:
All twiney were the ribbons straight,
And the pewter showed itself.

poem:
The Breyerslick

'Twas printshop, and the inky rolls
Did swish and schlock upon the plate;
All goopy were the pigment bowls,
And paper sheets did wait.

"Beware the Breyerslick, my child!
The teeth that grip, the drum that spins!
Beware the Splatterwhack, and wild
Inkblotters where it grins!"

She took her trusty scraper blade,
Long time the perfect tool she sought—
Then rested by the drying glade,
In pigment-thoughts, deep thought.

And as in oily thought she stood,
The Breyerslick, with rollers flame,
Came whiffling through the workshop wood,
And squelched as forth it came!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The carving tools did snicker-snack!
She sliced its rubber core in two,
And took its handle back.

"And hast thou slain the Breyerslick?
Come to my arms, my printish heir!
O frabjous day! The ink runs quick!"
She chortled in her lair.

'Twas printshop, and the inky rolls
Did swish and schlock upon the plate;
All goopy were the pigment bowls,
And paper sheets did wait.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Lirrishine

'Twas gleamsome, and the splittergrain
Did weft and warple in the wood:
All shimmeresque the planks remained,
Where ancient oakbeams stood.

"Beware the Lirrishine, my son!
The teeth that gnash, the claws that score!
Beware the Graindersnatch, and shun
The ravenous Boardboar!"

He took his quarteraxe in hand:
Long time the perfect cut he sought—
Then rested by the Tumtum stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in ripplelight he stayed,
The Lirrishine, with eyes aflame,
Came whistling through the wooden glade,
And sparkled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The mastersaw did slice and sing!
He split it fair, he split it true,
And made the sawdust spring!

"And hast thou sliced the Lirrishine?
Come bask in glory, precious child!
These boards shall dance with rare design,
Their figures running wild!"

'Twas gleamsome, and the splittergrain
Did weft and warple in the wood:
All shimmeresque the planks remained,
Where ancient oakbeams stood.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Sprungwright's Tale

'Twas whirlwise when the springaled gears
Did chuff and chunker in the case;
All binding were the ratchet-fears,
As tempo slipped its pace.

"Beware the blued-screw's pinching might,
My son, its threads that grab and stick!
Beware the pawls that snap at night,
And let the wrenchman tick!"

He took his tensioned blade in hand,
Long sought the mechanism's heart—
Through chambers bright with oilmist grand,
Where dust-motes leapt and dart.

And as he probed in careful thought,
The sprungwright, wise in all his ways,
Heard clicks where metal-teeth had caught,
Deep in the clockwork maze.

One-two! One-two! His swift hands flew,
The blued-screw spun with flash and fire!
He fixed it fast, he fixed it true,
Drew tight the singing wire.

"O wondrous deed! The movement's free!"
He chortled in his joy sublime.
The gearwork danced in harmony,
Each tick in perfect time.

'Twas whirlwise when the springaled gears
Did purr and whisper in their place;
Now banished were the ratchet-fears,
As rhythm found its grace.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "parrel bead on a gaff". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Slitherbead

'Twas gleaming bright on mizzen high,
The parrel pearls did glaze and glean;
All whispery were the windswept sky
Where mastlines danced between.

"Beware the Slitherbead, my mate!
The coils that crush, the fangs that snap!
Beware the Cleatbird, and relate
No tales of what you trap!"

He took his sturdy marlinspike,
Long time the rope-fiend sought he there—
Then rested by the windward strike,
And stood in salt-sprayed air.

And as in raffish thought he stood,
The Slitherbead, with eyes of flame,
Came writhing through the hardwood good,
Swift slinking as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The trusty spike went snicker-slack!
He left it dead, and from its head
He took the gleaming track.

"And hast thou slain the Slitherbead?
Come windward, lad! Fair winds, hurray!"
He chortled in his seafarer's glee:
The parrels shone that day.

'Twas gleaming bright on mizzen high,
The parrel pearls did glaze and glean;
All whispery were the windswept sky
Where mastlines danced between.

poem:
The Sourwocker

'Twas glutenous, and the slithy dough
Did flump and bubblate in the bowl:
All goopy was the levain-flow,
And the wet mass did slowely roll.

"Beware the Sourwocker, my son!
The teeth that bite, the crust that cracks!
Beware the Poolish bird, and shun
The fearsome Fermentacks!"

He took his banneton in hand:
Long time the rising foe he sought—
So rested he by the proofing stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in floury thought he stood,
The Sourwocker, with eyes aflame,
Came whiffling through the kitchen-wood,
And burbled as it came!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The scoring blade went snicker-snap!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Sourwocker?
Come to my arms, my yeasty boy!
O frabjous loaf! O crusty joy!"
He chortled in his flour.

'Twas glutenous, and the slithy dough
Did flump and bubblate in the bowl:
All goopy was the levain-flow,
And the wet mass did slowely roll.

poem:
The Patchimend

'Twas threadling bright, the woven waste
Did fray and tangle in the bin;
All ravely were the scraps misplaced,
The worn cloth whispered thin.

"Beware the Patchimend, my dear!
The teeth that catch, the hands that bind!
Beware the Thimblethorn, and fear
The Needlesharp's design!"

She took her silvered pin in hand;
Long time the perfect stitch she sought—
So rested she by memory's stand,
And sat awhile in thought.

And as in indigo she dreamed,
The Patchimend, with shadows frayed,
Came snipping through the seams it seemed,
With scissors' dance displayed!

One, two! One, two! Through patch and thread
The darning needle flashed and flew!
She bound its tatters, stitch by stitch,
Till mended all anew!

"And hast thou tamed the Patchimend?
Come to my arms, my stitching star!
O wondrous day! The rips shall mend!"
She laughed in bright repair.

'Twas threadling bright, the woven waste
Now whole and healing in the bin;
All lovingly the scraps were placed,
The worn cloth born again.

poem:
The Nixietron

'Twas glimming, and the glassibulbs
Did pulse and pimmer in their frame;
All fizzy were the voltadurbs,
And the mist-tubes sprang aflame.

"Beware the Nixietron, my son!
The digits fierce, the sparking bite!
Beware the Zappergasp, and shun
The luminescent night!"

He took his tungsten blade in hand:
Long time the phosphor foe he sought—
Then rested by the zinzar stand
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in ohmish thought he stood,
The Nixietron, with eyes of eight,
Came whiffling through the copperhood,
Incandescent with hate!

One-two! One-two! His blade went snick!
The metal sparked, the vacuum burst!
He left it dead, its final tick
Had dimmed into the worst.

"And hast thou slain the Nixietron?
Come to my arms, my beaming boy!
O frabjous lamp! O bright ion!"
He hummed in glowing joy.

'Twas glimming, and the glassibulbs
Did pulse and pimmer in their frame;
All fizzy were the voltadurbs,
And the mist-tubes sprang aflame.

poem:
The Snazzleswish

'Twas murkling in the deepmost sea
When swivving fish did dart and gleam,
The merbels swooped in finny glee
While gourgewhales stalked the stream.

"Beware the Snazzleswish, my boy!
Its tailspike sharp, its mouthparts dire!
The way it swooshes to destroy—
Its eyes like ocean fire!"

He took his trusty gourgespear tight
And sought the beast through wavering dark,
Where splishing shapes in pale moonlight
Left trails of glowing spark.

The Snazzleswish came whiffling near,
Its scales all shimmerflash and shine,
Then SWOOP! The blade struck crystal clear—
The beast's last thrash divine!

"O frabjous day! The deed is done!"
The merfolk sang their bubbly praise,
While swivving fish, now free to run,
Danced through the murkling haze.

poem:
The Epistoleer

'Twas clinksome in the cedared shelf
Where dustly papers whiffled dry;
The lockbrace clinked all by itself,
While memory-moths went floating by.

"Beware the Epistoleer, my dear!
Its teeth that grip, its words that burn!
Shun inkheart's pool, and never peer
Where violet-venom letters turn!"

She took her sterling pen in hand,
Long time the fateful box she stalked—
Then rested by the clockwork stand
Where tick-tock guardians grimly walked.

And as in parchment-thought she stood,
The Epistoleer, with eyes of flame,
Came scritching through the rosewood,
Seal-snapping as it came!

One-two! One-two! Her silver nib
Went snicker-snap through ancient spine!
She struck its heart, she claimed its crib,
Left scritchlings in decline!

"O frabjous day! The truth set free!
What secrets in these pages shine!"
She twirled in merry-mounting glee,
While shadows fell in line.

'Twas clinksome in the cedared shelf,
The lockbrace now hung broken-dry;
The letter, written to herself,
Made memory-moths all butterfly.

poem:
The Clicketack

'Twas midnight, dark and staticky,
The ionowave did swish and sway:
All crackledom was sparkaly,
And copper bits did spray.

"Beware the Clicketack, my friend!
Its dits and dahs will fry your mind!
When finger-strikes make contacts bend,
Leave dottled code behind!"

He took his trusty 'scope in hand:
Long time the crystal source he sought—
Then rested by the filter band,
In measurement deep thought.

And, as in analog he thought,
The Clicketack, with brass ablaze,
Came tapping through the signal spot,
Key-bouncing through the haze!

One-two! One-two! His spring flew true,
The contact gap did slice and snap!
He tamed it, and with solder new
He fixed the tension gap.

"Now clean contacts have slain the beast!
Let clear transmission be our way!"
He pulsed in joy, and at the least,
Sweet code flew out that day.

'Twas midnight, clear and static-free,
The ionowave did pulse and play:
All signals sent so craftily,
And copper sang hooray.

poem:
The Dusterdraw

'Twas shimblick, and the crinkletones
Did wheeze and warble in the gale;
All mizzly were the violones,
And their bowstrings wept and wailed.

"Beware the Dusterdraw, my sweet!
The cloud that chokes, the mist that blinds!
Beware the Scrapewhisk's rasping feet,
And shun the Rosinwind!"

She took her father's burnished blade,
Long seasons spent in searching forth—
Through misty mountains, music-made,
From southern seas to north.

And as she stood in thought profound,
A Dusterdraw, with eyes aflame,
Came drifting through the practice ground,
Its powdered path of pain!

The sword went snicker-snap! And through
The poisoned air she pirouetted—
Till particle by particle flew,
And harmony was netted!

"O frabjous day! The dust is clear!
The strings sing sweet and pure again!"
The crinkletones rang crystal-clear
As music flowed like rain.

'Twas shimblick, and the crinkletones
Did wheeze and warble in the gale;
Now pristine were the violones,
And their bowstrings tell the tale.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plane iron camber". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Wimberblade

'Twas slattern, and the skiving plane
Did grist and gimble on the bench:
All knurly were the boards profane,
And the yew scraps clinch-wrench.

"Beware the Wimberblade, my son!
The teeth that tear, the curve that bites!
Beware the Snafflegrasp, and shun
The furious Straightedge's fights!"

He took his trusty strop in hand;
Long time the steely foe he sought—
Then rested by the sharping stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in honing stance he stayed,
The Wimberblade, with bevels keen,
Came slithering through the sawdust grade,
Its camber flashing clean!

Snick-snack! Hone-whack! And through and through
The tempered steel did sing and spark!
He ground it flat, then curved it true,
And burnished out the mark!

"Have you now tamed the fearsome blade?
Come tell me of your destined task!"
"The shavings curl, the edge is made—
What more could father ask?"

'Twas slattern, and the skiving plane
Now smooth and gimble on the bench:
All silken are the boards so plain,
And the yew scraps clinch-wrench.

poem:
The Orinbellum

'Twas glissig, and the snazzleflax
Did sworl and wibble in the grime;
All mopsy were the rattletacks,
And the murp-birds chimed their time.

"Beware the Orinbellum, son!
The teeth that gnash, the wings that flare!
Beware the Zugglebeast, and shun
The Crimblesnatch's glare!"

He took his vorpal blade in hand:
Long time the fearsome foe he sought—
Then rested by the Tangle-stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in duskish doubt he stood,
The Orinbellum, flames aglow,
Came whiffling through the Murky Wood,
With eyes of indigo!

One, two! One, two! His blade sang bright,
The silver steel went snicker-snap!
He left it dead, and through the night
He rode the moonward gap.

"And hast thou slain the Orinbellum?
Come to my arms, my radiant boy!
O frabjous day! The beast is numb!"
He chorgled in his joy.

'Twas glissig, and the snazzleflax
Did sworl and wibble in the grime;
All mopsy were the rattletacks,
And the murp-birds chimed their time.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quenching brine hiss". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Salterpent's Song

'Twas brilling by the foamful shore,
Where wavelets spish and spray,
The grimblesnakes did writhe and roar
While merstrels swam away.

"Beware the Salterpent, my child!
Its venom burns like frost,
Through brackish deeps and currents wild
Have sailors' lives been lost."

He gripped his pearlpoint sword with pride,
His wetleaf armor gleamed,
Then dove beneath the rushing tide
Where danger lurked and streamed.

And as he swished in searchwake bold,
The Salterpent came near,
Its scales of bitter-bright and cold,
Its fangs of crystalled fear.

Swish-slash! Swish-slash! The blade rang true
Through brine-mist thick as night,
The beast's fell coils split clean in two,
Its hiss dissolved in flight.

"O joyous day! O splendent feat!"
The merfolk dance and sing,
While on the shore, where salt-winds meet,
The victory bells still ring.

'Twas brilling by the foamful shore,
The danger now has passed,
Where once the beast did writhe and roar,
Peace ripples free at last.

The Brangerbeast

'Twas snazzling, and the crinkled vines
Did weft and wangle in the gloam:
All brobbly were the meadowspines,
And the gripe weeds roamed.

"Beware the Brangerbeast, my child!
The claws that clutch, the teeth that gnash!
Beware the Badgerbloom so wild,
And ventures done in rash!"

He took his thorned blade in hand:
Long time the knotted foe he sought—
Then rested by the Tangle-stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in muzzled thought he stood,
The Brangerbeast, with eyes aflame,
Came snuffling through the twisted wood,
And grumbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The thorned blade went snipper-snap!
He left it dead, and with its bloom
He wound his way back, trap by trap.

"And hast thou slain the Brangerbeast?
Come to my arms, my whiskered boy!
O frabjous day! O feast of feast!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas snazzling, and the crinkled vines
Did weft and wangle in the gloam:
All brobbly were the meadowspines,
And the gripe weeds roamed.

poem:
The Scribblestab

'Twas bristling when the microtines
Did swarf and scribble on the page:
All flimsy were the fountain lines,
And the nib points showed their rage.

"Beware the Scribblestab, my friend!
The scratchy stroke, the blotted spray!
Beware the Meshmark bird, and tend
Your pens before they fray!"

He took his trusty polishing rod
Long time the perfect grit he sought—
Then rested by the writing pod,
In smoothening thought.

And as in silken strokes he sat,
The Scribblestab, with nibs aflame,
Came skritching through the writing mat,
As it scratched and scarred its name!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The micro-mesh did shine and shave!
He smoothed it flat, and with a "Whew!"
The demon's scratch he gave.

"And hast thou tamed the Scribblestab?
Come flourish here, calligraphic child!"
He penned his joy, each flowing stab
Now graceful, smooth, and mild.

'Twas bristling when the microtines
Did swarf and scribble on the page:
All flimsy were the fountain lines,
Till nib points lost their rage.

poem:
The Krenovore

'Twas gloaming in the slithy vale
When misted wings did swish and sway,
All throatsome were the cloudbirds pale
That wheeled throughout the day.

"Beware the fierce Krenovian beast,
My child, its talons rend the sky!
Keep watch from North to South to East,
And heed its hunting cry!"

She took her vorpal blade in hand,
And donned her father's silvered mail,
Through misty heights and clouded land
She tracked the monster's trail.

And as she stood in tensioned might,
The throated terror, flames unfurled,
Came shrieking through the fading light
With pinions dark and curled!

One, two! The blade went snicker-flash!
The steel sang true through neck and wing!
The beast fell earthward with a crash,
A burnt and broken thing.

"O frabjous day! The deed is done!"
The vale rings clear with victory,
And misty wings, at setting sun,
Drift peaceful, wild and free.

'Twas gloaming in the slithy vale,
The cloudbirds soar in gentle sway,
No throatsome terrors breach the veil
That guards the closing day.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "rain on a tin roof". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Dripplethrash

'Twas sloshing, and the pitter-drops
Did ping and plonk upon the shed:
All splishly were the puddletops,
And rain-wraiths wept o'erhead.

"Beware the Dripplethrash, my son!
The teeth that splash, the claws that pour!
Beware the Splatterwhump, and shun
The fierce Torrentialroar!"

He took his weatherblade in hand:
Long time the storm-fiend sought he there—
Then rested by the drumming-stand,
And stood in squelched despair.

And as in wetsome thought he stood,
The Dripplethrash, with eyes of hail,
Came sluicing through the thunderwood,
And sloshed its silver tail!

One-two! One-two! His blade so bright
The stormsteel flashed through waves of gray!
He left it dead, and through the night
The raindrops fled away.

"And hast thou slain the Dripplethrash?
Come drip, my squelchy boy, with pride!
Oh frabjous day! The storm we'll dash!"
He chortled as they dried.

'Twas sloshing, and the pitter-drops
Did ping and plonk upon the shed:
All splishly were the puddletops,
But sunshine gleamed ahead.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sencha kyusu drip". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Senchawock

'Twas steeping, and the verdant leaves
Did swish and swoostle in the pot;
All misty were the bamboo eaves,
And moisture pearled, both cool and hot.

"Beware the Senchawock, my son!
The teeth that bite, the steam that burns!
Beware the Chashaku bird, and shun
The fierce Kyusurath's churning turns!"

He took his copper strainer firm:
Long time the sacred spout he sought—
Then rested by the Tencha term,
And stood awhile in brewing thought.

And as in umami thought he stood,
The Senchawock, with leaves aflame,
Came whiffling through the bamboo wood,
And gurgled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The strainer mesh went snicker-snap!
He drained it dry, and with its brew
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Senchawock?
Come to my cup, my frothy boy!
O frabjous taste! O perfect wok!"
He steeped in his joy.

'Twas steeping, and the verdant leaves
Did swish and swoostle in the pot;
All misty were the bamboo eaves,
And moisture pearled, both cool and hot.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Dodgerator

'Twas lurking, where the printroom dims
And filter-glasses steam and swale;
The negatives hung chromium-slim,
While focus-knobs grew pale.

"Beware the Dodgerator, son!
The timer-click, the paper-burn!
Beware the Contrastax, and shun
The Bromide's point of no return!"

He grabbed his easel sharp and true:
Long time the perfect print he sought—
Then rested by the safelight new,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in darkroom deep he strayed,
The Dodgerator, eyes aflame,
Came whiffling through the gelatin shade,
And dodged as forth it came!

Snip-snap! Click-clack! The blades rang bright!
The burning tools blazed left and right!
He caught the beast, its shadows tight,
And fixed it in the light!

"Has thou subdued the printing fiend?
Come to my arms, my printroom boy!
O masterful day! Let prints be screened!"
He beamed his silver joy.

'Twas lurking, where the printroom dims
And filter-glasses steam and swale;
The negatives hung chromium-slim,
While focus-knobs grew pale.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Kiridashi's Tale

'Twas glimmer-gloam, the scribbly sheets
Did whiff and whisper on the bench,
The scoring blade, all sharp and slench,
Made scritchly sounds like paper bleats.

"Beware the Kiridash, my friend!
Its bevel-bite will mark and mar,
And keep thou from the Pencilbar
Whose graphite-grasp brings works to end!"

He took his trusty angle-vise
In hand, the marking gauge held tight;
Then rested near the workbench light
Where line-mist swirled like forming ice.

And as he stood in deep perplex,
The Kiridash, with edges keen,
Came slashing through the space between,
Its metal-mouth agleam with flex!

One, two! One, two! His tools rang true,
The straight-edge flashed, the squares held fast!
The beast, its fury fading last,
Scored perfect lines both straight and true.

"Have you inscribed the fearsome thing?
Let's celebrate your mastery!"
The workbench glowed with artistry,
While scribe-marks made the surface sing.

'Twas glimmer-gloam, the scribbly sheets
Did whiff and whisper on the bench,
The scoring blade, now friend not fench,
Made crafting songs like paper sweets.
